bibl.title: Letter from Robert M. O'Reilly to the Secretary of War, March 30, 1908

div1.p: O'Reilly relays that no harm could result from delaying the date of the imposition of quarantine against Cuba. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Robert M. O'Reilly to the Secretary of War, March 30, 1908
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON-GENERAL
WASHINGTON,
March 30, 1908
Memorandum for the Secretary of War:
X X X X X X X
div1.p:
The Adviser to the Department of Sanitation of the Cuban
Government is a very efficient medical officer who possesses the
entire confidence of this Department, and who, although not formal-
ly a part of the Reed Commission, really took part in its debates
and proceedings, and was also in consultation with Colonel Gorgas
at the time the latter officer cleaned yellow fever out of Havana.
He has at present a Sanitary Organization which I think would keep
him advised of any yellow fever in the Island.

I do not think that any great harm would or could result
from delaying the date of the imposition of quarantine against Cuba
until the Government of Cuba was given an opportunity to satisfy
the President of the freedom of the Island from yellow fever. This
should not be a matter of more than four or five days.
div1.closer: (Signed) R. M. O'REILLY, Surgeon-General, U. S. Army.
